[H1] Role of the ECL Cell in Peripheral Regulation of Gastric Acid Secretion.
[H1] INTEGRATED CONTROL OF GASTRIC ACID SECRETION BY NEURAL AND HUMORAL PATHWAYS.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Vagus acts directly on parietal cells and indirectly by effects on gastrin and histamine release.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Histamine released from enterochromaffin-like cells (ECL cells) reaches parietal cells by local diffusion.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Gastrin released from antral G cells reaches parietal cells by systemic circulation.

[NUMBERED_ITEM] Inhibitory regulators include somatostatin released from D cells in antrum and body of stomach and intestinal hormones collectively termed “enterogastrone”, and prostaglandins from surface cells.
Gastrin release from G cells of the antrum is stimulated by luminal amino acids and digested proteins and is inhibited in a paracrine fashion by somatostatin in response to luminal acid.
Somatostatin is released when pH is < 3.0
[H1] ACID SECRETION AND INTRAGASTRIC pH FOLLOWING A SIRLOIN STEAK MEAL.
[H1] ACID SECRETION IN RESPONSE TO INTRAGASTRIC SALINE (DISTENSION) AND FOOD.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Proteolytic enzyme secreted by chief cells as an inactive precursor, pepsinogen.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Release stimulated by vagal nerve and by presence of acid in stomach.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Activated by peptide cleavage at acid pH.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Initiates digestion of protein. It is an endopeptidase and active at acid pH
[H1] THE MOLECULE OF INTRINSIC FACTOR AND ITS COBALAMIN COMPLEX.
[NUMBERED_ITEM] Glycoprotein of Mol. Wt. 55,000 which binds Vitamin B₁₂ (cobalmin).
[NUMBERED_ITEM] After binding B₁₂ it binds receptors on ileal absorptive cells and is internalized by endocytosis.
[H1] Sequential Steps in the Absorption of Cobalamin (Vit B $_{12}$ ).
